Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CHS: Human in the Loop: Safety for Semi-autonomous Driving Systems in Emergency Situations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human-cyber physical systems (CPS) are systems in which the functions of intelligent machines and human operators are well integrated. Such systems have become increasingly pervasive, from intelligent manufacturing systems to smart homes to automobiles. The existing intelligent technologies aim at reducing human workload and increasing system safety, yet they also bring new safety concerns. These concerns are particularly essential in emergency situations, in which the human operator may be required to make decisions under time pressure and high-level stress. The decisions made in these situations are often the most important ones that can cause severe safety issues. This CRII project investigates influential factors for human-CPS system safety in emergency situations, using the semi-autonomous driving system as a concrete domain. The project outcome will improve our understanding of the safety-critical factors for semi-autonomous driving, inform the future design of other human-CPS systems, and ultimately lead to a more efficient and safe world.

Specifically, the inclusion of human drivers in the semi-autonomous systems makes the control tasks of the system more difficult because the controller must allow for unanticipated input from the human driver. Most existing work on the safety of such systems assumes a priori models that are expected to fully characterize human behaviors. However, such assumptions may become invalid when the human operator has to make a decision in emergency situations, such as car crashes or malfunctions. The goal of this project is to investigate systematically how the human-CPS system as a whole reacts to such situations and examine influential factors of the human driver, the vehicle sub-system, and the interaction. The proposed assessment measures of system safety in emergency situations include human performance in response to unexpected hazardous events, and human decision making during vehicle malfunctions caused by cyber attacks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate factors that affect the interaction between the human driver and semi-autonomous vehicles especially in emergency situations, with the ultimate goal of ensuring system safety and security. We conducted a series of human-subjects studies to examine human responses and decision making in emergency situations caused by unexpected hazardous events (e.g., sudden automation failure, jaywalker) as well as potential cyberattacks. 

Using semi-autonomous driving systems as a concrete domain, our research has advanced science for human-Cyber Physical Systems (CPS) by (1) investigating how human trust in the vehicle develops overtime, and how it is influenced by the vehicle's status (e.g., automation failure, take-over-request), (2) examining drivers' interaction with autonomous vehicles during potential cyberattacks in automated vehicles, (3) designing decision-support systems (e.g., directional, semantic collision warning system) for safe driver responses, and (4) assessing the effective response methods (e.g., directly operating the vehicle vs. confirming the vehicle's decision) for the human driver to take over the control from the vehicle.

The scientific findings will benefit the semi-autonomous driving research and design community and the field of human-CPS interaction at large. The results of this project were disseminated through scientific publications and presentations at national and international conferences. This project helped establish PI Chen's research program in human-automation interaction, and supported graduate and undergraduate student researchers, many of whom were female and minority students. Outreach activities involving preK-12 students and students from under-resourced families, as well as public lab tours, promoted STEM education in the general public and broadened participation of underrepresented groups in STEM.
